persistent_hyperglycemia_global.shape: Sustained high flat plateau with minimal peaks and valleys
persistent_hyperglycemia_global.actions:
0. Take a closer look into patient data and context details
1. Review current medication regimen and adherence
2. Assess carbohydrate intake and meal timing patterns
3. Refer to provider for potential medication adjustment, initiation, or dose increase
4. Educate on carbohydrate counting and portion control
5. Set A1C and time-in-range goals with patient

frequent_hypoglycemia_global.shape: Consistent valleys distrubuted aross multiple times a day
frequent_hypoglycemia_global.actions:
0. Take a closer look into patient data and context details
1. Review all hypoglycemia episodes for timing and potential triggers
2. Assess patient blood glucose lowering medications (insulin, sulfonylureas, meglitinides)
3. Refer to provider for immediate medication reduction
4. Assess meal timing, carbohydrate intake, and physical activity patterns
5. Educate on hypoglycemia recognition, treatment, and prevention
6. Recommend increasing CGM low alert threshold (75-80 mg/dL)

high_glycemic_variability.shape: Rollercoaster wings, wide band with unpredictable peaks and valleys
high_glycemic_variability.actions:
0. Take a closer look into patient data and context details
1. Identify patterns of highs and lows throughout the day
2. Review carbohydrate consistency and meal timing
3. Assess insulin dosing accuracy and timing (if applicable)
4. Educate on pairing carbohydrates with protein and fat
5. Refer to provider for potential medication adjustment
6. Endocrinology referral/escalation

overnight_compression_low.shape: Sudden steep vertical drop that is very flat and sharp without gradual increase/decreases
overnight_compression_low.actions:
Recommend fingerstick verification, if off by > 20 mg/dl, then likely compression low. Recommend switching sensor and moving to another site.

1. Review CGM trace and look for characteristic compression pattern (sharp drop and rise, v-shape), a true hypo will be a gradual slow decline

nocturnal_hypoglycemia_moderate.actions:
1. Do not give corrections after dinner (biggest reason), but change insulin dose before dinner to prevent corrections
2. Taking insulin before dinner, not after
3. Reduce/retime basal;
4. Adjust bedtime correction scale
5. Reduce evening alcohol
6. Relax BG targets control in older pts (75yr)
7. Less insulin around if excercise around dinner

nocturnal_hypoglycemia_severe.actions:

early_morning_hypoglycemia.shape: Decline that is gradual, curve is a gentle slop then dip
early_morning_hypoglycemia.actions:
1. Reduce/split basal insulin (too much basal)
2. Midnight snack +insulin -- should eat nuts or cheese that doesn't need insulin
3. Most common reason - AID insulin pump patients

mid_morning_hypoglycemia.shape: Rising and fast drop below range
mid_morning_hypoglycemia.actions:
1. Adjust meal time insulin
2. Less glycemic meal + protein and fat

afternoon_hypoglycemia.actions:
1. Reduce lunch bolus dose by 10–20% or adjust carb-to-insulin ratio.
2. Encourage consistent small lunch or snack even if using GLP-1 RA.
3. Review basal insulin timing/dose if exercise in afternoon → consider temporary basal reduction or post-exercise snack.
4. Educate on insulin sensitivity increase after exercise → monitor CGM more frequently within 4 hours.
5. Limit alcohol intake and avoid drinking without food.

evening_hypoglycemia.actions:
1. Reduce dinner bolus by 10–20% or use lower insulin carb ratio for post-exercise dinners.
2. If evening exercise common → reduce basal dose or add bedtime snack (15 g CHO + protein).
3. Encourage post-meal glucose check and CGM alert set at 80 mg/dL for pre-warning.
4. Limit alcohol before bed and pair with food if drinking with dinner.

pre_bed_hypoglycemia.actions:
1. Consider reducing dinner bolus or basal rate in evening.
2. Encourage bedtime snack (15–20 g CHO + protein if BG < 110 mg/dL).
3. Avoid vigorous late-evening exercise or adjust insulin accordingly.
4. Educate on delayed hypoglycemia risk after alcohol and importance of bedtime BG check.
5. Set CGM alert for < 80 mg/dL overnight.

dawn_phenomenon.shape: Stable overnight baseline followed by gradual rise and peaking before breakfast, without prior lows, appears as a smooth upward slope from flat overnight shape
dawn_phenomenon.actions:
1. Titrating medications, basal, metformin
2. Excercise close to bedtime (improve insulin sensitivity after 5hrs)
3. Insulin pump adjustment
4. Complex carbs with fat & protrein (greek yourt and nuts etc)

somogyi.shape: V-shaped night curve, dip then overshoot shape
somogyi.actions:
1. Titrating medications, basal, metformin
2. Excercise close to bedtime (improve insulin sensitivity after 5hrs)
3. Insulin pump adjustment
4. Complex carbs with fat & protrein (greek yourt and nuts etc)

prolonged_overnight_hyperglycemia.shape: Sustained elevation overnight without variation, flat high line
prolonged_overnight_hyperglycemia.actions:
1. Reduce late carbs
2. Excercise during the day or night 
3. Sleep quality 
4. Increase basal insulin 
5. Avoid high fat meal for dinner
6. Confirm bedtime and 03:00 readings to rule out post-dinner carryover.

dual_peak_double_spike.shape: Two distinct peaks that return to baseline, double-hump, camel-back shape
dual_peak_double_spike.actions:
• Use split-bolus or extended bolus if on insulin (e.g., 50 % upfront, 50 % 1.5–2 h later for mixed meals).
• Pre-bolus 15–20 min before eating to match digestion rate for high-carb foods.
• Reduce fat and refined-carb combination meals (pizza, fried foods, creamy sauces).
• Add non-starchy vegetables or fiber to slow carb absorption.
• If non-insulin user → take metformin/GLP-1 RA before large meal to blunt postprandial glucose.
• Post-meal light activity (10–15 min walk at 60–90 min) to flatten the second rise.
• Review CGM for delayed peaks > 3 h post-meal → adjust future dosing or meal composition.

day_to_day_variability_eg_weekends_certa.pattern_name: Day to Day Variability (eg., weekends, certain weekday)
day_to_day_variability_eg_weekends_certa.shape: Alternating stable vs high/lows days that differ by day of week, patchwork pattern
day_to_day_variability_eg_weekends_certa.actions:
Reduce weekend alcohol or late-night snacking.
• Track “trigger days” (e.g., work stress, long commutes) and implement behavioral countermeasures (mindful eating, pre-packed lunch).
• For insulin users: consider small basal adjustments (± 10 %) if patterns repeat on certain days.
• Educate on sleep consistency—aim ≥ 7 h; circadian disruption can raise fasting glucose.
